payload.name: argumentation-theory
payload.core: Model reasoning as directed graph of arguments and attacks; compute accepted claims via extension semantics (grounded, preferred, stable). Unit of analysis is argument-attacks-argument, not rule-defeats-rule or thesis-meets-antithesis.

key_concepts.attack: A attacks B iff A's claim contradicts B's premise or claim (undercutter vs rebuttal)
key_concepts.defense: A defends B iff A attacks all attackers of B
key_concepts.extension: maximal conflict-free set where each member is defended by the set

semantics.grounded: unique minimal extension built iteratively from unattacked arguments
semantics.stable: preferred extension that attacks all non-members
semantics.skeptical: claim accepted iff in ALL preferred extensions
semantics.credulous: claim accepted iff in ANY preferred extension

out.d: nodes = arguments, edges = attacks; format: {args: [{id, premises, claim}], attacks: [[src,tgt]]}
claims in chosen extension with semantics label
for each rejected claim: attacking argument and why defense failed
claims neither accepted nor rejected under skeptical semantics
which attacks, if removed, would flip acceptance status

proc: enumerate claims: list all propositions under dispute with unique IDs
construct arguments: for each claim, build support chain 〈P1..Pn → C〉; each premise must be grounded or another argument's claim
classify attacks: for each argument pair, determine if attack exists and type (rebuttal: attacks claim directly; undercutter: attacks inference step)
select semantics: grounded for unique answer, preferred for alternatives, stable for complete partitions
compute extension: apply Dung-style fixed-point or labeling algorithm
document rationale: for each OUT claim, trace attack chain; for each IN claim, trace defense chain

decision_steps.q: Do you need a single definitive answer or multiple defensible positions?
Are there cycles in the attack graph?
decision_steps.yes: grounded may leave claims undecided; consider preferred

decision_steps.q: Are premises verifiable or themselves disputed?

check: every claim has at least one supporting argument or is marked axiom
attack edges typed: rebuttal vs undercutter
no orphan arguments (disconnected from any claim under dispute)
conflict-free: no two arguments in extension attack each other
admissible: every attacked member is defended by another member
rationale traces complete for all OUT claims
sensitivity analysis run on at least 2 critical attacks
quick_checklist: graph drawn or serialized before computing extension?
premise truth assessed independently of argument strength?
absent counterarguments flagged as assumption risk?

defeasible.boundary: defeasible uses rule priorities to resolve conflicts; argumentation uses attack/defense graph with extension semantics
defeasible.test: if you're assigning priorities to rules, use defeasible; if you're modeling which arguments attack which, use argumentation

dialectical.boundary: dialectical seeks synthesis from thesis-antithesis; argumentation partitions into accepted/rejected without merging
dialectical.test: if the goal is to create a new integrated position, use dialectical; if the goal is to determine winners among fixed positions, use argumentation

rhetorical.boundary: rhetorical optimizes persuasion for audience; argumentation evaluates logical attack/defense regardless of audience
rhetorical.test: if output is a communication strategy, use rhetorical; if output is a labeled graph of accepted/rejected claims, use argumentation

assurance-case.boundary: assurance-case requires traceable evidence at leaves per GSN/ISO standards; argumentation accepts premises as given or recursively argued
assurance-case.test: if every leaf must cite dated evidence asset, use assurance-case; if premises can be stipulated or argued, use argumentation

legal.boundary: legal adds burdens of proof, jurisdiction, and institutional authority; argumentation is domain-neutral
legal.test: if burden allocation (who must prove what to what standard) matters, use legal; if you only need to know which arguments survive, use argumentation

confusions.symptom: user builds priority ordering over arguments instead of modeling attacks
confusions.resolution: defeasible resolves by rule specificity/priority; argumentation resolves by graph-based defense relation. If no natural priority exists, argumentation is more appropriate.

confusions.symptom: user expects synthesis output but receives accept/reject partition
confusions.resolution: argumentation partitions positions; dialectical integrates them. Chain: argumentation first to identify surviving positions, then dialectical to synthesize if needed.

fail.desc: treating dialectical victory as epistemic truth; undefended claim assumed false rather than merely undefended
signals: accepted claim reported as 'true' rather than 'defensible given stated arguments'
rejected claim treated as proven false rather than undefended
missing counterarguments not flagged as model incompleteness
premise truth inferred from argument survival
rhetorical skill (articulation quality) confused with logical structure

mitigations.test: each premise has explicit truth-status annotation: verified | assumed | disputed
output includes 'assumptions' section listing known argument gaps
two columns in output: dialectical-status (IN/OUT/UNDEC) and epistemic-status (verified/assumed/disputed)
at least 2 'what-if attack removed' scenarios documented

use: multi-stakeholder governance decisions with explicit pro/con structure
policy dispute resolution where positions are fixed and must be ranked
design review: enumerate objections, determine which survive scrutiny
ethics review: model arguments for/against action, compute defensible position
requirements conflict resolution: which requirements 'win' under stated constraints
ADR (architecture decision record) justification: document why alternatives were rejected

rel.r: use when rule priorities are the conflict-resolution mechanism
chain after argumentation when synthesis of surviving positions is needed
use when goal is persuasion of specific audience, not logical defense
normative claims appear as argument premises; combine for ethics disputes
use when arguments must terminate in traceable evidence assets
use when institutional authority, precedent, and burden of proof apply

ex.sit: Architecture decision: adopt microservices? Stakeholders present arguments; ops team is large.

premises: large ops team can handle complexity

steps: graph: A1, A2 support 'adopt'; A3 supports 'reject'; A4 defends A1 by attacking A3
grounded extension: {A1, A2, A4} - A3 is attacked by A4 and undefended
accepted: 'adopt' (supported by A1, A2); rejected: 'reject' (A3 defeated)
sensitivity: if A4 removed, A3 enters extension; 'adopt' becomes contested
ex.insight: context (ops team size) instantiates A4; argumentation surfaces that this premise is load-bearing for the decision

micro_example.situation: Two-argument cycle: A attacks B, B attacks A (e.g., 'prioritize speed' vs 'prioritize quality')
micro_example.grounded_result: both UNDEC - no unattacked starting point
micro_example.preferred_result: two extensions: {A} and {B} - credulously both accepted, skeptically neither
micro_example.action: escalate to decision-maker or add third argument that breaks cycle
